newsitem.title: CANADA: WIC family hails court ruling.
newsitem.headline: WIC family hails court ruling.

text.p: The family that founded WIC Western International Communications Ltd on Thursday applauded an appeal court ruling that upheld their control of the broadcaster.
"I am very happy with the outcome," said Emily Griffiths, matriarch of the family. "WIC has been preoccupied for too long on this matter."
CanWest Global Communications Corp and two former WIC directors appealed a decision by a lower court that effectively blocked CanWest's C$636 million takeover bid for WIC last year.
The British Columbia Court of Appeal rejected their arguments on Thursday. That decision was in line with expectations.

Winnipeg, Manitoba-based CanWest said it would not appeal the ruling. CanWest vice president Leonard Asper said the company would continue to hold its 15 percent stake in WIC's non-voting Class B shares and seek to build a more "meaningful" relationship with WIC's management.
CanWest and the former WIC directors were challenging WIC's two-tier share structure.

That structure allows the Griffiths family to control WIC by virtue of owning most of its voting Class A shares even though the family holds only about seven percent of the company's total equity. The appeal sought to have voting rights awarded to non-voting shareholders.

A ruling in favor of CanWest would have made WIC vulnerable to a takeover bid, analysts said. CanWest recently purchased another block of WIC non-voting B shares, bringing its holding to 15 percent. It said it believed itself to be the company's biggest holder of the B shares.
WIC has faced mounting shareholder unrest amid complaints the company has performed poorly and is unresponsive to stockholders.
The Griffiths family said in their statement that the company was "one of Canada's largest and most innovative communications company."

"The Griffiths family want to see WIC continue to grow and prosper for the benefit of all shareholders," Emily Griffiths said. WIC owns some of the most valuable properties in Canadian broadcasting including eight television, 12 radio stations and a share of Canada's CTV network.
